column6: storage_suggestions
Store greens in the refrigerator in a container lined with dry paper towels. Be sure not to pack the leaves too tightly.

Store the bananas on your countertop. To keep them fresher longer\, wrap the stems in plastic wrap. Note\, bananas will also speed the ripening of any nearby fruits \(give off high levels of ethylene\).

Apples benefit from being stored in the refrigerator as quickly as possible. They are best stored around 30-35 degrees F\, in a humid environment. Place them inside a crisper drawer and lay a slightly dampened paper towel on top.
Refrigeration helps halt the ripening process of avocados. If only using half of the avocado at a time\, keep the half with the pit and drizzle with lemon juice to keep from browning.

To pre\-wash the berries and help them last longer\, wash them in a diluted vinegar bath \(1 cup vinegar plus 3 cups water\)\, then spin dry in a salad spinner lined with paper towels until they are completely dry. Store in a sealable container lined with paper towels and allow moisture to escape by leaving the lid slightly ajar.

Cucumbers should be stored at room temperature\, not in the refrigerator. Be sure to keep the cucumbers away from other fruits \(especially bananas\, tomatoes and melons\)\, as they are highly sensitive to ethylene. They can tolerate up to three days of cold storage. If sliced rather than whole\, store in a plastic bag with a wet paper towel.

Store garlic at room temperature in a dry\, dark place that has plenty of air circulation\, or else they will mold and sprout. It stores better if kept as a head\, instead of broken apart into cloves. Peeled garlic stays best in an air-tight container in the fridge\; if peeled\, you should aim to use it up in a day or two.
Treat fresh herbs like a little bouquet of flowers\; put them in a glass of water \(e.g.\, shot glass or mason jar\) in the refrigerator. Snip off stalks as you need them.

Arrange the herbs lengthwise in a single layer on a slightly damp paper towel\, rolling them up like a jelly roll\, then transfer the bundle to a plastic zipper lock bag or wrap it in plastic wrap. Store in the refrigerator.
Store in a plastic bag in the vegetable crisper of the refrigerator.
Keep tomatoes at room temperature or in a cool\, but not cold\, location\; refrigeration stops the ripening and\, therefore\, the development of flavor.
Place the cauliflower in a plastic bag and keep in the refrigerator.
Refrigerate zucchini and yellow squash\, unwashed\, in a plastic bag in the vegetable drawer.

Assuming the peaches are ripe and you are not quite ready to eat them\, store in the refrigerator. Note\, the cold air in the refrigerator can be dehydrating. If unripe\, store peaches at room temperature.

Loosely wrap the broccoli heads with a paper towel so that the towel absorbs some of the moisture. Keep in the fridge. Do not wrap the broccoli too tightly with the paper towels\, seal in a plastic bag or keep in a sealed container.

Uncut ripe melons should keep in the fridge for up to five days. If unripe\, store at room temperature. Note\, keep ripe melons away from other fruit so that the ethylene gas that they produce does not speed up the ripening of the fruit.

Store brussels sprouts in a plastic bag in the crisper drawer of the refrigerator. Note\, sprouts still on the stalk will stay fresh longer than those sold individually. If you do not plan to use them right away\, stick the stalk in water and put it in the fridge \(as you would do with fresh herbs\)\; break sprouts off the stalk as needed.

column2: Butternut Squash\, Acorn Squash\, Spaghetti Squash
column6: Store your fresh\, uncut winter squash in a cool\, dark place\, such as a basement or closet\, where sunlight won\'t hasten its ripening. Note\, if cut\, the squash will last in the refrigerator for only about four days.

Ripe plums \(like other stone fruit\) keeps best in the refrigerator. Note\, store plums at room temperature to ripen. To speed up the ripening process\, place plums in a paper bag and store at room temperature\, away from direct sunlight.

Pre\-packaged mushrooms should remain refrigerated in their original packaging until ready to use. Loose mushrooms or ones in an open package should be stored in a paper bag in the refrigerator\'s crisper drawer\, which allows for better airflow and slight humidity to prevent from drying out.

Eggplant is likely to last longer when stored at room temperature. Keep eggplant in a cool spot\, away from direct sunlight\, and use it as soon as possible after harvesting or buying. You can place it in a vented bowl\, but avoid sealing it in a plastic bag\, which can increase decay. Note\, eggplant is similar to cucumber in that it is temperature\-sensitive and ethylene\-sensitive. Cooked eggplant may be refrigerated up to three days.

Place ears of corn in your refrigerator as soon as possible. Leave the husk on\, if possible\, and let the corn sit in the fridge uncovered. Ideally\, the temperature will be kept at or below 40 degrees F to prevent natural sugars in the corn from turning to starch.

Dry bulb onions should be kept in a cool\, dry\, well ventilated place. Do not store whole onions in plastic bags. Lack of air movement will reduce their storage life. One way to extend the shelf life of a sweet or high water content onion is to wrap each one in paper towels or newspaper and place them in the refrigerator to keep them cool and dry. Chopped or sliced onions can be stored in a sealed container in your refrigerator at the proper temperature of 40 degrees F or below for seven to 10 days.
Potatoes do not need to be refrigerated and should ideally be stored in a dark environment. Potatoes have a tendency to start sprouting or going bad at more humid temperatures.
Place carrots in a bowl \(remove green stems first\) and cover with plastic wrap or its sealable lid. Then\, place in the refrigerator. Change out water once a day to keep carrots fresh and crunchy.

Fill a jar or plastic bag with an inch of water\, store the asparagus upright \(this is easier if you leave a rubber band around the bunch\)\, cover with a plastic bag and keep in the refrigerator. Change the water when it gets cloudy.
